channel.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
channel.description:
How would you remove multiple instances of a character from a string for example The String moparscape has to a's. i just want it to be moparscpe, how would you do so
Or jennifer has 2 e's and 2 n's so the result would be jenifr. any solutions? I just want to know different ways to achieve this, so far i only have one solution

item.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:36, topic:549958”]You should use the least-specific type on the LHS, this makes it easier for refactoring if any ever needs to be done and also allows you to change to a different type w/o breaking compatibility because you used a feature that’s within LinkedHashSet but not in TreeSet.

Have a source for your claims? Seems pretty moronic that people would read the first word, Set, and automatically assume it’s just a Set (which doesn’t even exist because Set is just an interface and cannot be instantiated anyway!), the implementation of the Set is on the RHS, if you can’t read one line of code thoroughly to determine what instance of the type is being instantiated, you shouldn’t be programming.[/quote]If you always use the least specific type, why did you not use Collection instead of Set? It has both methods you used (contains and add), and Set doesn’t have any methods that Collection doesn’t. The reason is that the type helps define the purpose of the variable, so you use the least specific type that defines the required properties of the variable. And in this case, you used Set because it makes it clear that you are storing one of each letter, and I suggest using LinkedHashSet because it makes it clear that you care about the order objects are placed in. The important part is that in this example you are relying on the properties of the LinkedHashSet to make the code work. If you used a different Set the code would break, in exactly the same sense that you couldn’t use just any ol’ Collection.

@ Rest - Having one set that can be in order does not mean a HashSet is ordered or that a Set cares about insert order, so I don’t see how that implies it would be impossible. You’d have to not know how interfaces work to assume that pretty much anything is impossible, you could have one that stores them based on how close their hash compares to pi if you wanted. Doesn’t mean you’d be wrong to say Sets dont store based on relativity to pi. But yes, there is a Set that stores in order that could be used for this code, it’s just not HashSet

Read full topic
item.source: Removing multiple characters for a string

item.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:35, topic:549958”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=668838.msg4473188#msg4473188 date=1424285047]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=668838.msg4473181#msg4473181 date=1424283788]

lol i was just thinking you could store the word characters into a HashSet if you wanted to do it the lazy way
[/quote]except a set wouldnt store them in order, you’d end up having to iterate over the whole thing again anyway since you couldnt build it directly from the set

LinkedHashSet maintains insertion order – like I did in my OP
[/quote]Yeah, but he said HashSet.

As a side note, looking at your code, you really should say its a linkedhashset and not a set when you are defining the variable. The reason behind this is that because of the major importance of the fifo aspect of the linkedhashset in this code. IE - Someone that was looking at documentation or using an IDE would see that the variable was a set when hovering over, but perhaps it wouldn’t tell them it was a linked set. Then it wouldn’t make any sense. Yes, you can use the highest applicable class/interface when defining a variable, but at the same time you should make sure the code makes sense. Just like when defining a sorted set (when the sorting is a key aspect of the set) you should define it as a [tt]Treeset<> map = new TreeSet<>()[/tt], not Set<> map = new TreeSet. I myself am guilty of this quite often.[/quote]

You should use the least-specific type on the LHS, this makes it easier for refactoring if any ever needs to be done and also allows you to change to a different type w/o breaking compatibility because you used a feature that’s within LinkedHashSet but not in TreeSet.

Have a source for your claims? Seems pretty moronic that people would read the first word, Set, and automatically assume it’s just a Set (which doesn’t even exist because Set is just an interface and cannot be instantiated anyway!), the implementation of the Set is on the RHS, if you can’t read one line of code thoroughly to determine what instance of the type is being instantiated, you shouldn’t be programming.

Edit: I wasn’t replying to him, I was replying to you.

Davidi2:

except a set wouldnt store them in order, you’d end up having to iterate over the whole thing again anyway since you couldnt build it directly from the set

Implying no set would store them in order, hence the response of LinkedHashSet

Read full topic

item.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:34, topic:549958”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=668838.msg4473181#msg4473181 date=1424283788]

lol i was just thinking you could store the word characters into a HashSet if you wanted to do it the lazy way
[/quote]except a set wouldnt store them in order, you’d end up having to iterate over the whole thing again anyway since you couldnt build it directly from the set

LinkedHashSet maintains insertion order – like I did in my OP[/quote]Yeah, but he said HashSet.

As a side note, looking at your code, you really should say its a linkedhashset and not a set when you are defining the variable. The reason behind this is that because of the major importance of the fifo aspect of the linkedhashset in this code. IE - Someone that was looking at documentation or using an IDE would see that the variable was a set when hovering over, but perhaps it wouldn’t tell them it was a linked set. Then it wouldn’t make any sense. Yes, you can use the highest applicable class/interface when defining a variable, but at the same time you should make sure the code makes sense. Just like when defining a sorted set (when the sorting is a key aspect of the set) you should define it as a [tt]Treeset<> map = new TreeSet<>()[/tt], not Set<> map = new TreeSet. I myself am guilty of this quite often.

item.source: Removing multiple characters for a string

item.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

In addition, perhaps one of the most important parts of the pattern are the parenthesis. Any parts of a regular expression inside parenthesis are called capture groups, and when you find matches you can refer to those groupings how AtomicInt_ said. So the (.) is the first letter group, (.*) is the second group, which is basically the text BETWEEN the repeated letters and, \1 is a third part of the regex which isn’t grouped, which is basically just a reference to the first group (the first letter). We don’t group that one because we are just going to discard it. The replace basically says “ok, stick group 1, the first letter, and group 2, the letters in the middle, back into the text, but discard the repeated letter”.

You can get an idea of what is happening with this code:

[code=java] String text = “Jennifejr”;

    // Creates a regular expression pattern instance that is case insensitive.
    Pattern p = Pattern.compile("(.)(.*)\\1", Pattern.CASE_INSENSITIVE);
    
    // We are going to loop until we are done replacing.
    while (true) {
        
        // Create a matcher based on the current text using the compiled pattern. 
        Matcher m = p.matcher(text);
        
        // Can the matcher find any instances of the regular expression in the text?
        if (m.find()) {
            
            // Replace the text, removing the second copy of the character.
            text = m.replaceFirst("$1$2");
            
            System.out.println(text);
            continue;
        }
        
        // No more matches found, end the loop.
        break;
    }
    
    // All done!
    System.out.println(text);[/code]

Jennifer Jennifr Jenifr Jenifr

[quote=“x1 att ftw x, post:29, topic:549958”]Thanks! Helps alot, im going to look into using more of Regex from now on. in terms of efficiency, whats more efficient? using Regex or using the Contains or index of solutions?[/quote]I would assume one of the simple string builders is the most efficient.

Read full topic

item.source: Removing multiple characters for a string

item.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

x1 att ftw x:

What does line 2 do? and line 5? never seen something like that before

A pattern is a compiled representation of a regular expression; I’ll try and break up David’s post for you:

(.) - matches any except line breaks (equal to [^\r\n])
(.*) - matches 0 or more of the preceding token
\1 - references the first capturing group

The matcher is used to find a match, respecting the compiled regular expression, and while it can you are able to do 3 kind of match operations; Matcher#matches, Matcher#lookingAt and Matcher#find

If the matcher can find a match within the specified text (Jennifer) replace the first subsequence of the input (Jennifer) with the given replacement; the given replacement is ‘$1$2’

$# captures a group and inserts the result of the capture into the specified group

Then iterate and repeat until there are no more matches

Read full topic
item.source: Removing multiple characters for a string

item.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Pattern and Matcher are actually the classes you normally use when you’re dealing with regular expressions in Java.

Basically, Pattern is the class that represents a regular expression, and has a few utilities (such as case insensitivity, which was actually talked about in the thread) to help do more complex regex operations.

For example, if I replaced that line 2 with:

Then:
[tt]Jenniferj[/tt]
would become:
[tt]Jenifr[/tt]

because it is no longer case sensitive, so the last j is still removed.

So basically, just think of “Pattern” as an instance of a regular expression.

The Matcher on the other hand is somewhat like an iterator over all of the possible regex matches in a given string (char sequence). You use these classes when you want to find regex matches, not just replace/split, etc, because it gives you more tools to deal with them.

Just take a look at
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html
and
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/regex/Matcher.html
to get the general ideas.

Read full topic

item.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

This should make the regex a bit easier to understand:

String text = "Jennifer"; Pattern p = Pattern.compile("(.)(.*)\\1"); Matcher m = p.matcher(text); while(m.find()) { m = p.matcher(text = m.replaceFirst("$1$2")); } System.out.println(text);

By looping you eliminate the need for the lookaheads which is what confuses a lot of people. (Obviously the single regex is better to use of course)

Read full topic

item.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[code=java]
private static String removeDuplicates(String string) {
Set visitedCharacters = new LinkedHashSet<>();

	for (char character : string.toCharArray()) {
		if (visitedCharacters.contains(character)) {
			continue;
		}

		visitedCharacters.add(character);
	}

	StringBuilder bldr = new StringBuilder();
	visitedCharacters.forEach(bldr::append);

	return bldr.toString();
}[/code]

Regex solution:

private static String removeDuplicates(String string) { return string.replaceAll("(.)(?=(.*))(?<=(?=\\1.*?\\1\\2$).+)", ""); }

Read full topic

item.source: Removing multiple characters for a string

item.title: Removing multiple characters for a string
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:11, topic:549958”]Why not this?:

[code=java]package com;

public class StringReplace {

public static void main(String[] args) {
	String test = "hello";
	String another = "HELLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPPZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZ";
	System.out.println(replaceIndex(test));
	System.out.println(replaceIndex(another));
}

private static String replaceIndex(String phrase) {
	String newPhrase = "";
	for (int i = 0; i < phrase.length(); i++) {
		char current = phrase.charAt(i);
		if (i == phrase.indexOf(current)) {
			newPhrase += current;
		}
	}
	return newPhrase;
}

}[/code]

Output:

helo HELAOPZ [/quote]That’s literally exactly what he just posted. You just used [tt]indexOf != i[/tt] instead of [tt]!contains[/tt], which does exactly the same thing.
